Finally, I just wanted to enumerate the major predictive successes of Dr. Krugman's economic modeling and reasoning framework:

1. Early diagnosis of the liquidity trap condition and correct prediction of its monetary consequences.

2. Correct prediction of the tragic consequences of the austerity measures before they even implemented.

3. Correct prediction of the insufficiency of the 2009 Stimulus Package shortly after its details were announced.

All these predictions were contrary to the predictions of the vast majority of economists and politicians. It should be more than convincing for anyone who still has three or more brain cells.

It's not clear if you're promoting "tests in general" or "high-stakes testing." Almost everyone supports some degree of testing/evaluation, even if it is weekly spelling tests designed by the classroom teacher.

The major objection is to high-stakes testing, used for various purposes, including teacher ratings. I am sure you know, as a professor of education, that larger scale "standardized testing" is not really a test of learning, but many discriminatory (in the sense of discrimination as as making distinctions between) rankings based on complex statistical formulas. Tests like the SAT are based on bell-shaped curve to have certain proportion of students rated against each other, rather than "raw score."

I think you need to be clear about your position, rather than saying "testing is good for students" in some general way. Mostly you are saying: you will be tested all your life, so you are so lucky to get a chance to practice when you are young. This begs the question about issues like the ethics of testing, the (inappropriate) use of testing, the commercial value of profit-making testing companies, and all that goes into the testing controversy. It sounds like a lazy answer, and might score low on a test of essay writing.

Hi Barry,
If spending on specialty drugs will grow from 25% to 40% of spending within 5 years, wouldn't that suggest that the pace of developing specialty drugs has accelerated due to an increased market? Isn't that how companies think?

And while Medicare part D is only 6 years old, Medicare part B was covering cancer drugs delivered by IV. Wouldn't the fact that it was covering costly cancer treatment delivered in a hospital setting but not other prescription drugs until recently suggest that we were more interested in covering expensive new treatments than established plain ones .

The Medicare part D benefit was bipartisan, and the motives for passing it may vary, but I think you can view the decision not to allow Medicare to negotiate lower drug prices as an attempt to encourage the development of new treatments, and not simply as a way to "enrich" drug companies.

In any event, the high deductibles that insurers are now offering in the bronze ( soon to be copper? ) plans are not about encouraging people to use generics instead of name brand. Or to favor less expensive therapies over more expensive ones. If that was the goal, the plans could use tiered pricing, or differential pricing. No. The high deductibles are about forcing people to use less care. Period. The saying is doctors who self treat have fools for patients. But somehow patients with no medical training are supposed to know what's the best treatment is for them.

What makes HFT troubling is not that it's fast, and not even that its practitioners get to see results a fraction of a second faster than everyone else. The problem is that they can make a trade, and then cancel it if turns out not to be profitable. That should be illegal.

It is hard to comprehend why you & others are surprised or astounded by this behavior or believe that the wrongdoers are fooling themselves about anything other than getting caught - at least if they do not work for a TBTF firm.

Frequently references are made to the observation that one’s position on an issue often depends on that person’s financial interest in the outcome.

In addition to financial interest driving behavior the column appears to neglect the factor that not all people are good or ethical. In a large organization what percentage can one expect to find of those who do not feel bound by rules or laws? Perhaps they are an Ayn Rand devotee & believe they are above the rules & laws that govern the rest of us or just an ordinary sociopath who has not invested the effort into finding justification via Ayn Rand?

In fact the purpose of laws is to protect the rest of us from conduct that would occur but for laws & we know that such conduct would occur because it has occurred in the past & there are those who will engage in wrongdoing without feeling any need to "fool themselves."

"..Money is what can be used to buy things. Historically money has first been specie (gold and silver coins), then fiat money which is paper currency and checking accounts (M1) and more recently credit money. The credit money supply is what in aggregate can be bought on credit. Two hundred years ago your ability to take your friends out to dinner depended on whether or not you had enough coins (specie) in your pocket. One hundred years ago it depended on the quantity of currency in your pocket and possibly the balance in your checking account if the restaurant would take checks.
Today it is mostly your credit card that allows you to spend. We no longer have a fiat money system. Today we have a credit money system. Just because there is still some fiat money does not negate the fact that we are on a credit money system. When we were on a basically fiat money system there was still a small amount of specie in circulation. Even today a five cent piece contains about 5 cents worth of metal, but no one would claim we are still on a specie money system.

The effective money supply is the sum of the traditional fiat money aggregates plus the credit money supply. Thus, despite the claims of Ron Paul and Rick Perry to the contrary, the effective or true money supply has fallen drastically over the last few years...."

You've got to call it what it really is, HIGH-SPEED-INSIDER-TRADING. It's more than just skimming or scalping. It creates misperceptions about each target stock/company which can and does impact the market on the whole.

Intense, automated high-volume trading affects and misleads human traders about what is really happening in the market. As their algorithms detect micro-trends, the resulting super-fast bot trades accentuate and magnify those upward or downward trends.

HFT essentially interferes with fair market values and the basic dynamics of supply and demand.

Furthermore, fair market pricing, fair competition and fair valuations are concepts involving human cognition, not trading bots. Taking the human factor out of stock trades creates not only MISPERCEPTIONS but ILLUSIONS in the marketplace, perhaps even in the entire economy.
